topics.title: Introduction and Background
topics.summary: Gergely opens by contrasting Uber compensation with his current newsletter earnings, and Lenny introduces the episode’s focus: leaving big tech to run a paid newsletter full time and how to succeed at it.

topics.title: Sponsor Break
topics.summary: Sponsor reads for lemon.io (hiring vetted developers) and Eppo (A/B testing platform for modern growth teams).

topics.title: Career journey to The Pragmatic Engineer
topics.summary: Gergely walks through his engineering path from Hungary to the UK, Microsoft/Skype, Skyscanner, and Uber, culminating in an unexpected pivot to writing The Pragmatic Engineer newsletter.

topics.title: Newsletter scale, growth engines, and paid model
topics.summary: Gergely shares subscriber growth (including the impact of Substack recommendations), explains free vs paid tiers, and notes he relies primarily on subscriptions rather than ads/sponsorships.

topics.title: Income comparison: Uber compensation vs newsletter
topics.summary: He details his best Uber year (~$320–330k in Europe) and explains that the newsletter now earns more with upside tied to subscriber growth, unlike capped corporate compensation.

topics.title: Why leave Uber: promise, layoffs, and autonomy
topics.summary: They discuss the psychological shift from corporate security to creator work, and Gergely explains how COVID-era layoffs and a prior promise to take a risk pushed him to leave.

topics.title: Startup plan, self-publishing success, and fisherman story
topics.summary: Gergely describes intending to raise VC for a platform-engineering startup, then being pulled toward writing after self-published books earned meaningful revenue; he uses the fisherman parable to explain choosing the life he wanted now.

topics.title: Timeline from quitting to launching newsletter
topics.summary: He clarifies the ~10–12 month gap between deciding to leave and starting the newsletter, including Europe’s longer notice periods and reflections on middle-management constraints and control.

topics.title: Publishing cadence and the real work of writing
topics.summary: Gergely explains moving from one to two posts per week, why high-quality posts take days to weeks (research, drafting, feedback, editing), and how long-form writing compares to journalism output.

topics.title: Creating structure: deadlines, accountability, and serializing a book
topics.summary: They discuss how external commitments drive productivity; Gergely shares using the newsletter as a forcing function to eventually assemble his Software Engineer’s Guidebook, inspired by how The Three Musketeers was serialized.

topics.title: Sponsor Break
topics.summary: Sponsor read for Vanta, focusing on automating SOC 2 compliance to speed up security audits and unlock enterprise sales.

topics.title: Focus tactics: tools, timers, and blocking distractions
topics.summary: They compare strategies for deep work amid social media pull: Centered, Pomodoro-style timers, and Gergely’s host-file/script approach to block distracting sites until he gets into flow.

topics.title: Upsides of newsletter life: time and experimentation
topics.summary: Gergely highlights the benefits of an open calendar, fewer meetings, and being fully in charge—enabling rapid experimentation with formats and ideas.

topics.title: Downsides: loneliness, guilt, and creator stress
topics.summary: He describes missing team camaraderie, feeling guilt about perceived productivity compared to corporate life, and the surprising stress and isolation of running a solo, attention-driven business.
